topic.title: Configuring the Monitoring Service
topic.abstract: The monitoring service, based on Monasca, allows you to configure an external SMTP server for email notifications when alarms trigger. You also have options for your alarm metrics database should you choose not to use the default option provided with the product.In you have the option to specify a SMTP server for email notifications and a database platform you want to use for the metrics database. These steps will assist in this process.

section.title: Configuring Email Notifications
section.p: In order for the monitoring service to be able to send email notifications about alarms, it needs to be configured with an email server. The email server is not provided by , but must be specified in the configuration file described below. The email server must support SMTP.
You can specify your SMTP server either during the installation phase of your cloud deployment or post-installation if need be. We will show both methods below.
section.note: You may need to change the "From" email address for notifications if your email server rejects email from the default: notification@exampleCloud.com You can also specify the email address where notifications are sent; the "To" address. These can be configured either during or after initial installation. The instructions are provided after you configure the SMTP server.
section.p: To configure the SMTP server, edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/cloudConfig.yml file during installation. There should be a section at the bottom for smtp-settings that looks like this below. If it doesn't exist, you can add it:
section.codeblock: smtp-settings: # server: mailserver.examplecloud.com # port: 25 # timeout: 15 # These are only needed if your server requires authentication # user: # password:
section.p:
This table explains each of these values:
Value Description
Server (required) The server entry must be uncommented and set to a valid hostname or IP Address.
Port (optional) If your SMTP server is running on a port other than the standard 25, then uncomment the port line and set it your port.
Timeout (optional) If your email server is heavily loaded, the timeout parameter can be uncommented and set to a larger value. 15 seconds is the default.
User / Password (optional) If your SMTP server requires authentication, then you can configure user and password. Use double quotes around the password to avoid issues with special characters.

section.title: Configuring Email Addresses During Installation
section.p: You can edit one or both of the addresses used to send and recieve email notifications. The instructions are different for the "To" and "From" addresses. The instructions are also different if you configure the addresses during or after installation.

To configure the "To" email address, during installation,
Log in to the lifecycle manager (deployer).
Open the following file: ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-notification/defaults/main.yml
Find the following variable: notification_address. If it doesn't exist, you can add it.
Change the value to be the email address you want to use.
Save the changes to the file.

To configure the "From" email address, during installation,
Log in to the lifecycle manager (deployer).
Open the following file: roles/monasca-notification/defaults/main.yml
Find the following variable: from_addr:. If it doesn't exist, you can add it.
Change the value to be the email address you want to use.

section.title: After Initial Installation
section.p: If you need to configure a SMTP server or make changes to your existing SMTP server after your initial installation, these steps will show you how:

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

To configure the SMTP server, edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/cloudConfig.yml file. There should be a section at the bottom for smtp-settings that looks like the example below. If it doesn't exist, you can add it.
This example also provides descriptions of each line.smtp-settings: # server: mailserver.examplecloud.com # port: 25 # timeout: 15 # These are only needed if your server requires authentication # user: # password:
Ensure that you uncomment these lines by removing the hash (#) marks.
Commit your configuration to the local git repo, as follows: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
Run the configuration processor with this command: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Use the playbook below to update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Run the Monasca reconfigure playbook to deploy the changes: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-reconfigure.yml --tags notificationYou may need to use the --ask-vault-pass switch if you opted for encryption during the initial deployment.

section.title: Configuring Email Addresses After Installation
section.p: You can edit one or both of the addresses used to send and recieve email notifications. The instructions are different for the "To" and "From" addresses. The instructions are also different if you configure the addresses during or after installation.
To configure the "To" email address, after installation,

ol.li:
Log in to the Operations Console in a browser by entering either the URL or Virtual IP connected to Ops Console.
For example:https://myhelion.test:9095 https://VIP:9095
On the Home screen, click the menu represented by 3 horizontal lines.
From the menu that slides in on the left side, click Home, and then Alarm Explorer.
On the Alarm Explorer page, at the top, click the Notification Methods text.
On the Notification Methods page, find the row with the Default Email notification.
In the Default Email row, click the details icon , and then click Edit.
On the Edit Notification Method: Default Email page, in Name, Type, and Address/Key, type in the values you want to use.
On the Edit Notification Method: Default Email page, click Update Notification.

section.note: Once the notification has been added, running playbooks will not change it.
section.p:
To configure the "From" email address, after installation,
Log in to the lifecycle manager (deployer).
Open the following file: ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-notification/defaults/main.yml
Find the following variable: from_addr:. If it doesn't exist, you can add it.
Change the value to be the email address you want to use.
Save the changes to the file.
To commit the changes to your local git repository:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
To run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
To create a deployment directory:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
To run the reconfigure playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-reconfigure.yml

section.title: Choosing an alarm metrics database option
section.p: The monitoring service supports two different database options. The default metrics database is Vertica, which is a highly-scalable analytics database from HP. Vertica is free to use, up to 12TB, for all paid Helion customers as a Helion operational database . Vertica is the recommended database for .
You can learn more about Vertica here: Vertica Documentation
The alternative open source database option is InfluxDB. InfluxDB is an emerging open source monitoring database, however the current release contains the following limitation:

ul.li: InfluxDB cluster does not recover upon node failure.

sectiondiv.p: In order to replace the default database option with InfluxDB as the metrics database, you need to follow these steps:
During the Configure Your Environment portion of the installation, ensure you make these configuration file edits:

ol.li:
On your lifecycle manager, edit the following two files:
Edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml file and under your control plane cluster service-clusters section, edit the entry for vertica to read influxdb.
Edit the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/disks_controller.yml and either replace the existing vertica information or insert the information for InfluxDB as seen below in the section labeled for logical-volumes on the DISK_SET_CONTROLLER:
- name: influxdb size: 5% mount: /var/opt/influxdb fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file consumer: name: influxdb

Then, edit the file below to change the value of database_type to influxdb instead of vertica: ~/helion/hos/ansible/roles/monasca-variables/defaults/main.yml
Example: # Must be either vertica or influxdb database_type: influxdb
Then continue on with the installation steps as documented.
